p: Seroprevalence data suggest that exposure is common in early childhood [ 36]. More than 90% of adults are seropositive for at least 1 HCoV species [ 37]. A recent prospective active surveillance study of young infants in Nepal that used multiplex polymerase chain reaction (PCR) showed that HCoVs are less common in neonates compared with older infants [ 32]. Outbreaks of variable sizes have been reported sporadically in medical students, young asthmatic children, and neonatal intensive care units [ 38â€“41]. For example, an outbreak of HCoV-229E was reported in a neonatal intensive care unit where 92% of infected preterm neonates developed symptoms, including worsening respiratory conditions and bradycardia [ 42]. Potential nosocomial transmission by staff members was speculated.
